ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The fundamentals of TV writing and the TV industry
How to write a TV pilot and knowledge of the industry

This course gave me concrete strategies and building blocks to write a TV pilot, and allowed me to walk out with a full 60 page pilot written. Skills for building world, structure and writing itself were all taught

This course completely changed the way I think about creative writing. I took it as a fiction Writing Concentrator who's never written a script. By reading pilots, listening to Professor Tracy's phenomenal lectures, analyzing scenes, and writing a pilot of my own, I developed a sense of what it takes to write for TVbut better yet, I built up my repertoire as a writer. I was taking a fiction writing course at the same time and notice a massive improvement in my short stories; their narratives became more streamlined, their scenes tighter, and their dialogue punchier. I attribute all of this to Professor Tracy's course. Even if I stick with fiction, I'm so glad I made this foray into screenwriting.
Great practical understanding of the script-writing process, and lots of medium-specific craft skills like structure and scene work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very good overview of the TV industry as well as the fundamentals of TV writing; the readings are really fun!
Weaknesses: we didn't have a good discussion flow
I really enjoyed the industry advice and reading and discussing other pilots

ENGL 461 is one of the best creative writing courses I've taken at Yale. Professor Tracy is dedicated to helping each student grow as a writer, and his classes contained the perfect blend of lectures, discussions, flash-writing exercises, and writers' rooms. This course is also super helpful if you're hoping to enter the TV-writing business; Prof. Tracy organized Zoom meetings with Yale alumni who are working on upcoming TV shows and frequently gave advice on how to make it in the industry. I wished we could meet more frequently instead of once a week, but that's a necessary evil of most creative writing courses. I wonder what would happen if we'd had assignments due more often (i.e. aside from work for our pilots) and on other days of the week. What if, for example, we had a writing exercise to submit every Wednesday (the way we each wrote a teaser after our writers' room). I worried that after doing the week's work for Monday, I forgot about this course a bit until the next Monday came around. Other than that, though, ENGL 461 was perfect!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! You write your own scripts, a cool experience
Absolutely! If you are at all interested in TV writing, the TV writing industry, creative writing, or popular culture, this class is amazing!

This is the best screenwriting course Ive taken at Yale. Compared to other TV or film writing courses, this one (and this sequence) really clearly and practically teaches the skills to get a compelling story on the page and prof. Tracy clearly knows what hes doing. Would recommend

Absolutely! Don't be deterred if you've never taken a screenwriting class beforeI got in as a fiction writer and learned so much from Professor Tracy. Even if you're not planning to enter the TV industry, this course will revolutionize the way you approach creative writing. Highly, highly recommend!

extras.title: ENGL 461 01 - The Art and Craft of TV Drama
